editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE CARNIVAL: A Comedy. As it was Acted at the Theatre Royal, By His Majeſties Servants. Written by THO. PORTER, Eſq
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, and are to be ſold at his Shop at the Sign of the Anchor in the Lower-Walk of the New-Exchange. 1664.

list.item: Don Felices, a wild Fellow, Brother to Ferdinando.
Quintagona, Governanto to Beatrice and Miranda.

div.head: ACTUS I. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Ferdinando, Beatrice, at a low Window.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: PEdro, ſtay you there:
And whiſtle if any chance to paſs this way:
Let me not be ſurpriz'd I charge you.
Hem! Beatrice! my Life! Hem!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Hem! ſoftly: I come.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now all the bleſſings of Auſpicious Heaven
Fall on ſo beauteous and ſo kind a Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I now muſt owne this as my duty, Sir;
And yet I will confeſs,
That Love does prompt me to it with a joy
As great as yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Still kinder! and I moſt happy!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: But you did promiſe me, the other night,
You would prefix a time wherein my Brother
Should be acquainted with all what has paſt;
It were not kind to doubt his Love,
And keep him (in it) longer ignorant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My faireſt Beatrice, I'le tell you why
I hitherto have kept it from him:
That you and I are now made ſure
I ſtill ſhall thank your mercy for that goodneſs;
But he's unſatisfied in his affections,
Sad with deſpairing Love is froward grown,
Brooks no diſcourſe but what tends to his Cure.
If I can ſerve him in his buſineſs ought
I then make ſure of him too;
And I would fain remove all poſſibilities
Of Letts to my moſt wiſh'd Adventure here.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: And has he, Sir, implor'd your help?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'A has, to wait upon him as a friend,
And to ſecure his walks by night.
She is the Siſter to a man of Quality,
Though he be abſent now, imploy'd about
Some buſineſs in his Charge of Barcelona:
Her kindred being of the greateſt Rank
May boggle at the leaſt of Gallantry
To this young Lady without his admittance.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: You have not yet ſeen her?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No; but this time of Carnival
Allows more freedom then all the year beſides:
And in a Maſque we are reſolv'd to ſee
The Saint your Brother prays to.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: But my Fernando tell me when——

sp.speaker: Pedro within.
sp.p: Pheu! Pheu!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Be gone, be gone my Soul,
Here comes Company.
Who are they, Pedro?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Don Alvaredo, with your Brother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O! walk as if you came from his houſe.
Welcome, dear friend, I had ſent my Man
To ſee if you were at home.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: 'Twas thither I was going; I juſt now ſent my Servant To deſire you would come to me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'm glad my Fates have brought me to your wiſhes.
O Brother! 'tis a wonder to meet you:
How do you imploy your time?
Ha? merry ſtill! what device now on foot?

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Any to be doing,
Except making Love at Churches;
For there a man is bound at leaſt
To a ſerious look, (and that I hate)
Turning up the whites of your Eyes
Look more preciſe then a Dutch Puritan,
Or play tricks with your fingers
To tell the hour of viſitation:
When the poor vulgar think
You thereby count your Ave-Maries,
Having forgotten your Roſario.
Out on't! what a damn'd Device
To cloath Dame Venus in ſackcloth!

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Well, Gallant, would I had thy mirth,
And thou my Love.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: So would I, if ſhe be handſome.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nay, I mean the Paſſion I have for her,
Not her Perſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: O bezo les Manos Signior; I thank you for nothing:
But marry, prithee marry;
And to pleaſe you I will be in love with your wife,
Or any mans wife in Chriſtendom that deſires it:
And then we'l ſee what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Why what will come on't think'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Children, brave luſty Children, if ſhe be but kind as ſhe ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: Away Madcap; come let's in, Friend, I muſt now implore Your help and counſel.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Come, come, I muſt not have you ſo inquiſitive.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, if I do not ſerve ye both a trick—
What, do ye think becauſe I'm young
I cannot keep counſel?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: What counſel? what counſel?
I'de have you to know I'm no Counſel-keeper.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nay, on my Conſcience, I do believe thee, Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: You do ſo; well, well,
God ſend all Proverbs prove not true.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Prithee what Proverbs, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: E'en one I have often heard.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come out with't, out with't, good Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Marry I have heard them ſay,
Soon Ripe ſoon Rotten:
God bleſs thee, and ſend thee grace.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And thee wit.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: O have I caught ye?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A Rape! Nurſe, a Rape!
Run for the Alquazil,
He's a grave man, and will do women juſtice.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: I, run, Nurſe, run,
Your young Miſtreſs may be undone;
Is this your diligence?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Well Gallants, well,
Thus muſt I be abus'd and jeer'd:
I wonder what the Devil was in my Maſters mind
To give you leave to uſe his Siſter ſo;
He thinks ſhe's young, but if he knew her
As well as I, he would truſt her no farther then
He could throw a Milſtone.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Do you remember, Nurſe,
When you took away my young Miſtreſs from me,
And were, forſooth, ſo ſcrupulous.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: I, I, but ſhe is grown half an inch ſince.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: How good Nurſe! how doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Away you wag, I mean no harm.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Nor I truly, Nurſe;
But remember ſtill as I told you.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: What ſhould I remember?

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Why, how you were call'd:
I'le but repeat his words.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Nay, nay, good Sir, let it alone;
I'm ſure my heart has been ready to break ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alas poor heart!
Pray Signior Felices rub not old ſores;
She'll fall into a fit of the Mother.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: A fit of the Grandmother you mean, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha! O Donna Quintagona!

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: O Donna Quintagona!

sp.speaker: Mir. Feli.
sp.p: Cheri chink, cheri chink, cheri chink, tery chink chink.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: I'le not ſtay to be abus'd thus.

div.stage: Exeunt laughing and ſinging, Miranda, Felices.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Vizards I have got, and all the tricks and devices
Neceſſary for our Gambals; troth I have
A great mind to practiſe here a little
Upon theſe City Gallants; fools I'm ſure they
Are as well as we, only dreſt better, and
Keep their gravity more; for the firſt learned
Counſel a Mother gives the Don her child,
Though but of two years old, is, Guarda la
Gravidad. Hi, hi, hi, hi! Here's your fools face,
And here's your Don's:
sp.stage: looks fantaſtically, blowing up his cheeks.
sp.l: Pray which is better, to play the fool well,
Or to diſſemble the wiſe man,
And be an errant Cockſcomb here?
Why I have ſeen the Lord of our Village,
When he has been ask'd what a Clock 'tis,
Look on the Meddal of his Roſario, (as if
That could direct him;) and durſt not (as
We do) look in the Sun; for that dazling
Of him makes him grin, and then,
Boutoua Criſpo, a looſes his Gravity.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: Why Pedro! Pedro! come away Man!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I do, d'ye hear? pox, how a ſtays!

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: Why, what are you, friend?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: One of Gods making, and his own undoing.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: Prithee about thy buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: So I am. Oh! in good time.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hi, hi, hi, hi!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Oſſorio, what a Devil ails this fellow?

sp.speaker: Oſſor.
sp.p: He's mad I think; what Trade art of?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A Giber, ſweet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Oſſor.
sp.l: Why then about thy buſineſs, I ſay again;
For we are not for thy Turn.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: The propereſt men in Sevil.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.l: Nay, that we are not neither;
My Friend Pedro is not tall by any means.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: O Signior, I meant it not in that ſence.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Pray, Gentlemen, what's likeſt a Horſe and
Is no Horſe?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Oh I can anſwer that, I read it in a Book
T'other day; 'tis a Mare, friend.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.l: Troth and that's true; but I thought
Ye would have anſwered, an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: Well, come, ſuppoſe I anſwer ſo.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why then, Gentlemen, you come much
Nearer my Conceit;
For you two are as like one another
As one Aſs can be to t'other. Hi, hi, hi!

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: You Rogue, if I light on you—

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: What a Raſcall's this! But come,
Our Maſter ſtays for us.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I have her leave this night;
And yet I fear this favour may all turn
To my undoing.

sp.speaker: Ferdi.
sp.l: She cannot have ſo much of Marble
'Bout her heart;
Or indeed, why ſhould ſhe grant you this,
Without ſhe meant it kind?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: She bad me bring a friend with me,
And he ſhould judge between us of our Caſe;
Nay ſhe will freely there confeſs (ſhe ſays)
That her denial does not ſpring from hate;
For ſhe has ſo much Juſtneſs in her Nature,
To ſee that all the Actions of my Life
Are bent to court the honour of her Love:
And yet I fear ſhee'l never underſtand
An Argument ſo much to my advantage
As may confute her of her too much Coldneſs.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: This needs muſt be your fault:
Talk of a womans Coldneſs!
Why who ſhould warm the poor Wretches
But we? we who are the ſprightly active Animals,
And they the phlegmatick paſſive,
Sweet or not ſweet,
Leering or lowring viſible Creatures.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Peace, prithee, Brother, peace:
For ſhame ſhew not your mirth
When your poor friend lays open thus his wounds.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nay, let him talk;
I could wiſh that I could talk ſo too:
It moveth not my Anger but my Envy,
To ſee him in ſo much a better ſtate.
Stay here, we're near the houſe.
Come friend, now thou ſhalt ſee if I have
Cauſe to mourn,
That can behold the Joys of Heaven
Wrapt in Hells chiefeſt Torment, black Deſpair.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hope your Love, like Children in the dark,
Fancies the Bugbear you ſhall never ſee.
Brother, pray ſtay, and ſee that none come up this
Street till we are entred; I'le call upon you here.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Well, Gallants, remember ye owe me a watching.
Pedro! Oſſorio! are not you two ſtout enough
To keep this Streets end? I'le go but hard by,
And be back again before they come forth.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: O Lord! Sir, your Brother will take it unkindly.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, my Maſter will wonder if he hears on't.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: And I ſhould wonder if he did not hear on't,
As long as ſuch a Tadpole, Raſcally, Gurmudgeonly
Whelp as thou know'ſt it: Sirrah do you remember
The fright you put me and my poor Whore in
At your Maſters houſe, you Rogue? I got the
Whole truth out of him; and I yet owe thee
A beating for't, and now I have nothing
Elſe to do I will pay my debts.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, for Heavens ſake hold:
Here come • Company.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh cry you mercy, Sir!
I find you were buſie: pray, Sir,
Let not my preſence put any conſtraint
Upon your humour; but kick him again
Soundly; and that Fellow too, if your Worſhip
Pleaſes: you have my leave freely.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Your leave, Raſcal!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes my leave, Sir:
Why, I can give any body leave to kick me
If I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: I am one of thoſe never ask it,
Eſpecially of ſuch ſawcy Companions.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh, your humble ſervant, Sir:
Pray no farther; 'tis too much honour
I aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: This is the Rogue that jeer'd us to day.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: I, I▪ peace, peace, man:
The young Signior's blown;
How a pants!

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: This is the pleaſanteſt Rogue that e're I
Met with—

sp.speaker: Sancho within.
sp.p: Help! help! murther! murther!

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Ha, what's that? let's go ſee.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No help? good people help, help.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Come fellows, this way the Cry is.

sp.speaker: Enter Sancho.
sp.p: This way Gentlemen I'm.

sp.speaker: Enter Feli. &c.
sp.p: Where art thou? ſure 'tis ſome Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Peeps in Sancho.
sp.p: Hi, hi, hi, hi!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: 'Tis that Rogue jeers us.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: If I can but catch you—

div.stage: The Scene changes to a Parlour.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: But, Madam, muſt I never hope for more then this?

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: Pray ask this Gentleman
If I ha'nt dealt moſt like a friend,
That's plainly, with you, Sir:
The Laws of Gratitude make me deny
To tye a woman to you, when her heart
Is ſo averſe to what you now deſire.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Strange Paradoxes theſe, that out of Love
You will deny me what I moſt eſteem!
Well, Madam, I will leave you,
Never to ſee the world again:
I'le be your Beadſman, ſince I am deny'd
To be your Lover.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Stay Friend.
Madam, can any thing ſo fair
Have ſo much Cruelty!
Look with the Eyes of Juſtice on his Merits,
You'l find ſo rich a Jewel worth your Care.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: As which, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: As yonder Gentleman you ſo afflict:
And let me freely tell you, Madam,
'Tis peeviſhneſs,
Which is as far from Virtue——

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: As you from Charity,
To chide me for a fault
That you your ſelf are cauſe of.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: Come friend, there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Stay, I will have two words more.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: No, go with him;
But if you will return alone,
I'le tell you freely what you long to know.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha, I underſtand you—
Come, deareſt Friend, remember 'tis a woman,
Not worth the trouble of a gallant man;
Think on their follies and their weakneſs,
The ſcarcity of good ones in the Sex;
The danger you had run in the great plenty
Of evil, cunning, ſelf-will'd, hair-brain'd women:
And all theſe put together,
Thus I would part with Love,
And tread the Earth in liberty again.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: And thus would I adviſe a Friend to do:
But did you know the Paſſion I had for her,
How vain you would eſteem all ſuch advice!
And gueſs the world ſhould reel beyond its Orbe,
And mix in great Confuſion with ſome Star,
Ere I ſhould leave to love the fair Elvira,
Miſtreſs of all my Love and all my Hopes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, rather term her, Sir,
Miſtreſs of all the Cruelty and Scorn
A wilful woman ever yet did owne.
Why ſhould man loſe his Birthright, and proclaim
Himſelf a ſervant to a peeviſh Sex,
That from the firſt was meant a ſlave
To all his will and pleaſures?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Peace, Heretick! it were a ſin to hear thee.
'Twas force that firſt made Laws to be obey'd;
And that's the only priviledge that we
Can claim above thoſe beauteous Creatures.
Was the poor Lamb created for the uſe
Of wrongful, theeviſh, and of Ravenous Wolves?
Or was the Conſtant Turtle only fram'd
To be the Quarry of a Tyrant Hawk?
Theſe have our Plea, and had they induſtry
Would frame as Rigid Laws as we;
For all were not ſo ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: And it were juſtice they ſhould be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How much of baſeneſs then muſt all we owne,
That ſtoop and bow in ſuch humility,
And treaſonably court them from their ſtrength,
Which being Maſters of, we then proclaim
And uſe our uſurp'd priviledge?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Heyda, a womans Orator!
Pray heaven your Fee
Anſwers your Eloquence.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I care not, the fault ſhall all be hers:
But come, dear Friend, I ſwear I am not well.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Here I did leave my Brother. Ha! Brother! Pheu!

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: No matter, come.

div.stage: Enter Felices, leading in Sancho by the hair; Oſſorio, Pedro.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Oh Rogue! have I caught you?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Sure I have.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Why did ye ask the queſtion then?

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: A Wit too!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: The people of our Village think me one.

sp.speaker: [Pheu within.] Pedro.
sp.p: Yonder's my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Go, get ye both gone, I'le follow ſtraight.
Sirrah, what bundle of Trumpery
Have you got here?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Why, I hope you will not rob me.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Rob thee, hang thee, what is't?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, Sir, I was employ'd Deputy from
Our Village for Vizards and fools Bawbles:
You know to morrow is our Carnival.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: A pleaſant Rogue this: Sirrah, wilt thou ſerve
Me, I'le pay thee well; and I'le go down
With more Company to thy Village?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes; I think we ſhall be well met:
Like maſter like man.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Come then, follow me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: If ever thou beeſt ask'd which way I went,
Say home, directly home.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And thither go you now,
But if my Brother ſhould come home before me,
As he do's ſeldom uſe,
Say you have miſt me, know not where I am.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I ſhall not fail in ought.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What ſhould this woman mean,
She ſaid I was the cauſe of his repulſe;
Nay, ſhe did urge that he ſhould bring me thither,
I've ſeen her often at the Church with him,
And ſhe is fair, moſt Excellently fair;
But all the while that he diſcours'd with her,
My thought the moving Language of her Eyes
Did ſeem to tell me, had I been the man
That did implore her mercy, ſhe had then
Not been ſo cruel. —
Here is the houſe I hope ſhe doth Expect me,
Within, Who's there,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: 'Tis I, I parted juſt now hence.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: You'r wellcome, Sir,
Yet did I not expect you would return ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twere diſobedience, did I but prolong
The leaſt of your Commands, and that's a Crime
I never would forgive my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: And I can hardly be induc'd
To grant a pardon to my fooliſh ſelf
That now commit a fault
'Gainſt Womens Honour, and faire Modeſty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twere ſo; did you permit this favour to a man,
That brought not all the reverence, and reſpect,
So fair a preſence merits,
But you are ſafe from ſcandal,
Relying on the ſtrength of my diſcretion,
Farewell, all honeſty I am o'recome,
And am to weak to ſtruggle 'gainſt ſuch Charms.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: I hope your fair conſtruction will admit
No thoughts are tending to my prejudice,
You ſeem'd to think I was unreaſonable
In the denying Alvaredo's Love,
He is a Gentleman I much Eſteem,
But when he talks of Love, I loſe all that,
And almoſt grow to hate what I eſteem'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis true,
Love is a thing that cannot be conſtrain'd,
And if a heart not yieldeth of it's ſelf,
All force and ſtratagems are vain.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: You ſpeak moſt learnedly of a ſubject
I thought you had been ignorant in.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: As well you may deem him a cold
That's in a Calenture,
Or him that faints and melts away
Under the Torrid Zone;
Thoſe beauteous eyes can thaw a heart,
And make an Anchorite knowing in this Art.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Yet would he want this Eloquence
Without ſome practice,
I doubt I am not, Sir, the firſt
That you have ſtrove to flatter from themſelves.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: But when that doubt ſhall be remov'd.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I can but thank yee for your complement.

sp.speaker: Fer·
sp.l: Why will ye term it ſo?
Here ſhall I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, you go too far,
A Gallant yet did never want an Oath
For the undoing of a harmleſs Maid;
But grant I knew 'twere true,
What could you then Expect in Recompence.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nothing; for 'tis your due,
And what you e're ſhall grant of Love
I will call Charity; meer mercy to your Creature;
Nor will I trouble yee with tedious talk
How much I love and honour your fair beauty,
Since where the truth is cleer,
And in your power by any ſtrict Command
To put me to the teſt,
All circumſtance is Needleſs;
For, Madam, as I cannot live without yee
So I dare die, to ſhew how much I lov'd yee,

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: That were a teſtimony I'le never claime,
No live, and live to let me ſee your Love,
That is the firſt command I'le lay upon you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Proceed, dear Madam.

div.stage: Takes her in his Arms; ſhe puts him away.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: The next, and chiefly wherein I conjure ye
By all the vertue, faith, and honour in yee,
You ne're miſconſter this my eaſineſs,
Nor ever uſe a priviledge, or make an offer
To what may cauſe a bluſh.
Were the whole world our witneſs,
In recompence I'll promiſe to be kind,
And what my honour will permit, I'll grant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And by that tie I'll claim it;
Can ye vouchſafe a promiſe to be mine?
Your Brothers abſence, and this fitteſt time
Do's prompt us not to ſlip it.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: I dare believe yee, Sir.
Find you the means,
And I'll not fooliſhly pretend to know
Nothing of what I've given you cauſe to hope.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To morrow then I'll ſee you,
And bring a man ſhall ſo unite us,
Never to be parted:
The Streets are full of Gambols and of Tricks,
We ſhall not be obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Farewell, Sir, 'tis late,
And let my love preſerve the title ever,
That you to night have given it in your heart.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let all the bleſſings Heaven has yet in ſtore
Fall on my fair and kind Elvira's head.

div.head: ACTUS II. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Antonio, with a Guittar playing; to him Felices, Sancho.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: WHither away, dear friend; not know me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Felices, wellcome, wellcome, faith, ſo early up! 'tis
Scarce day, being up at play all night
I was going to Julianas lodging.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What, to play the Fidler under a whores Window!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away fool, 'tis the onely ornament of a melancholly
Lover, one that doats infinitely on all Women,
And cares not a ruſh for any one in particular:
A whore! why, hadſt thou ever a Miſtris thou didſt
Not wiſh to be ſo? then I have this
Advantage, mine's made one to my hand.
Prythee what fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh, an excellent Rogue I have pick'd up.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, one that was made ſo to his hand.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Come, come, prythee, let me go with thee,
Her maid will ſerve my turn, or any thing
That's Woman, I onely love the converſation of
The Sex, no harm in me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes, Signior, you may truſt my maſter,
And for my ſelf, I can do yee prime ſervice,
And ſleep (if occaſion ſerve) upon the ſtairs
Like a Statue half erected, or one whoſe props
Are warp'd, and ſo inclineth to the Centre backwards:
Ther's a Term you underſtand not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away ye Rogue;
Come here's the houſe, lets in.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: No, wee'll give the Donazellas
A Serenade firſt:
Sirrah, have ye no Caſtinets?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes Sir, here; pray give leave to keep time too
With this Inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, a Grid-iron?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I'll warrant you, ſhall be as good Muſick.
As any in Sevil.

div.stage: Antonio Sings, they Play the Chorus ſtill altogether.

lg.l: LOok out, for ſhame look out,
And put your Lover out of Doubt,
That thinks the Sun has loſt his light,
And that you run his Courſe to night.
Look out, for ſhame look out,
And put your Lover out of doubt,
That elſe may think he has loſt his way,
When not enlightned by your day.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Heer's ſtuff;
Nay, play on, play on, Sir, I can ſing
More to this Tune.

lg.l: Look out, for ſhame look out,
And put your Lover out of doubt,
Who's heart ſuſteins a cruel load,
Becauſe he thinks your gon abroad.
Look out, for ſhame look out,
And put your lovers out of doubt,
Who elſe would leave to Bawle and ſing,
But that they think you are within.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Look out, for ſhame look out,
And ſhow to us thy dainty Snout,
Rather then wander in the Street,
sp.stage: Burſts open the door with his foot and Enters.
sp.l: Thus Doors we open with our feet.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: That was not ſo Amorous now;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, nay, let's go in playing.

sp.speaker: Enter. Fel.
sp.p: Fly, fly, the Enemy, the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Draws. Ant.
sp.p: What's the matter, man?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Sir, I'll run for help;
But if I come again.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Oh, Signior, ſix tall Whores able to Devour
A Regiment, O my Kidneys melt to think on't!
Why, I had rather fight with twelve the beſt
Men in Sevil, O Diabolo, Rampant, rampant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, doſt think Women can hurt us?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I, I, much more then men;
Why, they all leap'd about me like Fairies,
And ſmothered me with kiſſes;
Beſides, I ſpy'd one I have promis'd a new Gown too
This half year.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prythee, come in, Felices.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Not I, one at once, were ſhe the Devil, I durſt
Meet with; what charge a file of Whores!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, I'll not leave thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What hour of the morning thinks thou 'tis?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Tis very early, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And haſt thou been abroad?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Return'd ſo ſoon?
You have expreſt much Care;
But have you well perus'd the Markets, Bartolo,
And tane a ſpecial note of what was good?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Truly, I hope thou haſt; for I have ever found thee
Virtuouſly inclin'd: I have ſome Company muſt
Sup with me, friends, Bartolo, my worthy friends,
And I would not have them think me or
Thee ſo ignorant, but that we can chuſe
The beſt of every thing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Sir, elſe I had ill imploy'd my time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But to the point, good Bartolo,
What didſt thou ſee, prithee, let me hear thee?
A ſtool there, boy; theſe Rogues Eat, and Eat,
And never mind their waiting; ſome water
For my hands there; troth, Bartolo, I have had
An ill night on't, thou put'ſt too much Garlick in
Thy ſawces: Belches And yet I think 'tis good
Againſt the wind.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I can aſſure ye, Signior,
I have lick'd my fingers in your Lordſhips diſh this thirty years,
Yet can I boldly ſay, I never was bleſt with a juſter
Hand, then laſt night, in all the ſeaſonings.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I do not blame thee much,
May be it do's proceed from Melancholly:
There was a damn'd Colonel ſupp'd laſt night with me,
Cut up ſome ſix Pyes he never taſted of,
And fill'd the Wine himſelf, diſliking what was fill'd him,
And out of what Bottle think'ſt thou man?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Not out of that mark'd with L.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Yes, the ſame, the very ſame, good Bartolo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O Monſtrous, I never heard of ſuch an inſolence!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But I have thought of a ſafer means, hereafter
I'll have thee wait at the Table, and my Wine
Kept, ſo as no body but may ſearch the
Bottles at the Cup-board, yet never finde
The change was put upon them:
The rareſt conveyance, Bartolo,
I learn'd it of a wiſe Venetian, in my travels of Italy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And truly, my Lord, that is a ſubtle Nation.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It is ſo, for I have ſtudied much their way and manners.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: But pray, my Lord, how is this Wine to be convey'd?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I will prepare thee for it againſt night;
This Water is not from the fountain, Sirra,
But from the River, I ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, it comes from both.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis well, a little of all do's well, ha, Bartolo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: It do's ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What a Clock is it now; ſay you?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: The Sun's an hour high.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: S'death, and thou haſt not told me yet
What's in the Market, Bartolo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Pleaſe you, my Lord, to take your Pen in hand.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Begin, I have written in Primis.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: For Butchers meat, the time of the year
Will eaſily let your Lordſhip gueſs what it is.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: True, Bartolo, proceed to Fowl, and ſome Fiſh.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Shall I begin with Fiſh, or Fowl?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: With Fiſh, good Bartolo, with Fiſh.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, then my Lord I muſt aſſure you, I never ſaw
The Market better fill'd; for there was of the choiceſt
Store, but dear, extreamly dear.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That's wonderful,
For ſtore (they ſay) is no ſore;
But dearneſs is a ſore, nay, a great one, Bartolo,
It pales the appetite.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: It do's ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But to the particulars, good Bartolo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A brave Cods head.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A Cods head, man?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, a Cods head.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Prythee let me hear that again good Bartolo.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, a brave Cods head.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: So ſoon! why, by my account it ſhould not be
Theſe five days yet in ſeaſon;
But prythee on, where is this Cods head?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: In the Governours Kitchin by this time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yee Rogue, yee lie;
In the Governours Kitchin? They know not how to
Dreſs it; the Heavens would never bleſs them with the
Luck of ſuch a Rarity; a Cods head now!
So ſoon! it cannot be!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Tis true, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Slave, 'twas then thy fault:
This comes on thy drowzy hoggiſh nature;
You cannot riſe, you, nor look unto your Buſineſs, Sirrah;
I'le have you ty'd to cloſer duty, Dog,
And you ſhall turn the wheel below
With your own beaſtly weight.
Was ever man ſo curſt as I!
Such Servants! oh ſuch Servants!
I ſhall be ſtarved, or elſe be fed
With ſtinking Mackarel.
O the brave politick Italians,
That early riſe to buy their meat themſelves!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Truly, my Lord, it is not altogether my fault.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How, how can that be, let's hear?
Nay, I am reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Truly, I offered two Ryals.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well, and would not that do?
Would not that fetch it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: May be with entreaties I might have prevail'd,
And promiſes of further cuſtom;
But in came that villainous Caterer, and out-bid
Me ſix Maravedies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What Tyranny is this,
Snatch the morſel from my mouth!
The King his Maſter were he ſuch a Tyrant
Would finde no Subjects to owne him for their Prince.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Lord, here is a young Gentleman would
Speak with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: 'Tis young Signior Felices.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh tell him 'tis my writing day:
You know he is invited here to ſupper;
Tell him I ſhould be glad to ſee him then.
Come Bartolo, I'le write the reſt within,
And give thee all directions for this night.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Not ſpeak with me?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: He ſent you word you were invited to Supper;
And then (as I have learnt)
Is his time of ſpeaking.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But I would fain have known what Company.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh his Nieces, I'le warrant you, Sir,
And all his acquaintance:
To night's a night of mirth.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Sirrah, be ſure you make us ſome;
It was the only virtue I took you for.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, and I choſe you for the ſame reaſon.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: How's that, you Rogue?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, this is the way home.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou Arbitrator of all humane Fate,
That giv'ſt ſuch fair Idaeas to the mind!
Thou Paſſions Ruler, even that of Hate;
Nay, Maſter of each one to which th'art joyn'd!
Thou whom the wiſeſt do Miſguider call,
The Tyrant of our Reaſon, and our Will
Doſt make predominant, to Act in all
Without diſtinguiſhing of Good or Ill!
Thou that ſuch Flames canſt kindle in one hour,
Nay, thou that canſt thoſe violent Flames deſtroy,
Shewing a Maſter-Beauty, one whoſe Power
Is fram'd of all that's Love and all that's Joy!
Yet thou againſt thy ſelf haſt now rebell'd,
And brought new force where thou a Conquerour waſt;
And thy own Subject by bright Armes expell'd,
Whom as thy Viceroy in my heart th' hadſt plac't:
Shall I obey thee now? ſpeak, ſhall I love?
Remember what thou counſeld'ſt me before:
But who will judge but that I ſtill ſhall rove,
If thus I break what I ſo oft have ſwore?
I, but Elvira's fair: I, too too fair,
That ſuch polluted Sacrifice as I
Should dare unto her Deity appear,
Scorched before by Beatrices Eye.
Ha, her Brother!
Love hide thy ſelf, ſince now ſo guilty grown.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: What, melancholy, friend?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hope you are not ſo;
And know by this time 'tis a fooliſh ſin
To pine and languiſh for a womans Love.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: No matter what I think;
I'le live as merrily as thee,
Or any man in Sevil;
Hang looking pale, or hanging of the head:
Come let's be merry, very merry;
Where ſhall we dance to night?
Or ſhall we go to this peeviſh woman's,
That ſhe may ſee how eaſily I bear her ſcorn?
Come, wee'l go in Maſquerade;
Her frowns can neither make my Vizard bluſh
With grief nor ſhame.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This mirth is forc'd, come, I know 'tis;
Do not go ſee the Cauſe again;
There may be danger in't.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: And that's the reaſon I will go:
She then ſhall ſee I dare her ſhot;
Nay, would ſhe now be kind, I would not love again.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: I think I ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What, and ſigh? nay, nay, believe you that will.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Prithee don't think of her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Your Counſel comes too late.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou, friend?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I wiſh you did not, Sir;
Nor do not think of going thither.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nay, that I am reſolv'd of;
All things are ready for the Maſque;
Your Brother goes, and a friend or two more.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I'le wait on you in any thing.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How ill on outward ſhews we place belief!
My mirth is but my overflow of grief.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Come, come, Charge, I muſt not have
You melancholy; why, d'ye know where
We are going? why look up, I ſay, Charge, thou ſhalt ſee him:
You know, I know your mind.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Dear Nurſe, you know I've truſted you with all
The treaſure of my heart.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Well, well, and have I ever wrong'd your truſt?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I do not ſay thou haſt, good Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Why then be merry; be merry, or I'le be
Out of humour, and then who ſhall dance the Pavan
With Oſſorio?

div.stage: Sings, Si chirés que lo ramo.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Siſter, Siſter, Siſter! prithee come away, my Brother
Is almoſt ready.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Prithee, dear Siſter, take you good notice which is
Fernando; you may go any where, and ſee how
That he does diſguiſe: I would not be miſtaken
In the men.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: So they be not miſtaken in us, no matter.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: They cannot: me they'l know from thee
By my height.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And cannot you know Ferdinando by your heart?
You love? Piſh, if I were in Love I could follow
My Lover by inſtinct, (as a Dog does his Maſter
By the ſcent) at two Leagues diſtance.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Fye, Miranda, how thou talkeſt!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Fye, Siſter, how you are moapt!
If thou art ordain'd to love, love as I live, merrily.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I in love? away fool, I'le turn Nun ſooner.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do, good Siſter, do, it is a pretty melancholy vocation
That I am infinitely taken with:
Here's Quintagona ſhall be a Lady Abbeſs.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Why, you young Tit, I could diſcharge the office,
For all your grinning.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why, who ſays the contrary, good Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: You are always fleering;
But I ſhall fit you one day.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: With whom, good Nurſe? now I thank you.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: I won't go now, that I won't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Nay, prithee Nurſe. Why, Siſter,
Why doſt thou vex her ſo?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I? nay, dear Nurſe, no dudgeon;
You know I meant no harm.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Go, go, I'de truſt a Monkey in a Glaſs-ſhop ſooner.
Come, Charge, let's make our ſelves ready.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Prithee, Miranda, minde what I told thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'le warrant you; yes buz quite contrary,
I'le aſſure you, ſweet Siſter.
Felices, Signior Felices!

div.stage: Felices with his head to the door.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Here, little Miſtreſs, what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Can you make Love finely?

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Why d'ye ask? may be I can; who's to try?
I hope, ſince ſhe's too young her ſelf, ſhe ſet
One to pimp for me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Your name is Fernando to night;
Be ſure you lead my Siſter. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: What do's the urchin mean? I'll try,
And do as ſhe bids me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Prithee Bianca, peace, thou know'ſt not half my mind.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I'm ſorry, Madam, I've bore my ſelf ſo ill
As not to deſerve your truſt now.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Indeed, wench, I durſt tell thee any thing;
But where thou canſt not ſerve me,
The knowledge would avail thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: But ſtill it troubles me to ſee you penſive,
It may be ſorrow, and then I would be glad to ſhare your griefs;
If it be buſineſs you do meditate,
Too heads do's better far then one,
At leaſt in all I would expreſs my duty.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: I thank thy love and care,
And will e're long acquaint thee with my thoughts:
But Prythee now go touch thy Lute;
For Muſick is beſt Phyſick for a mind
So out of Tune as mine.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Madam, I will obey in All;
What will you pleaſe to hear?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: That which thou ſang'ſt me yeſterday.
Here are ſome Maſquers without, Madam,
Who deſire admittance; People of quality they
Seem to be.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Admit them: who can they be!
If it be Alvaredo he brings my Dear Fernando
With him; 'tis he, I know him
sp.stage: Enter Alvaredo, Ferdinando, Felices, Beatrice, Miranda, Quintagona & Sancho: Servants with Torches.
sp.l: By his Port.
You're wellcome Ladies;
Gallants, ſo are you:
I know you not, but this is kindly done,
And I muſt own the Obligation ever:
You ſee I take a liberty though in the abſence of
My Brother.

div.stage: They Bow, Point to their own Muſick for to play; Alvaredo takes Elvira by the hand, and whiſpers her.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: You ſee, Sir, I am civil,
If you hint not the old improper buſineſs, Love.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Oh, Madam, that is quite forgot:
You ſee I'me merry now.
Why ſhould we pine and grieve
For what we cannot help?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: 'Tis true; and I am glad to finde you in that humor.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is Excellent, moſt Excellent!
Ah, gallants, when I was a young man I lov'd this
Dearly; Oh, the brave Donzellas I have ſeen and lov'd
In my travels at Venice; there who but I!
My Gondalo follow'd by the beſt Muſick, ſtored with
The fineſt women; my table ſpread with the beſt
Of all things; and my Bottle fill'd with beſt verdu
Monte fiaskou vin Greco, Valga me Dios, it makes
Me mad to think on't. Prithee Signior Antonio, get
Your Siſter, the fair Elvira, to accompany theſe
Gallants to my houſe to night; I know them all,
They are kindred: there is no ſcandal
To an old mans houſe, a friend and ſervant to the
Count her Brother; her father was my worthy
Friend, but thoſe days are paſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll do my beſt, my Lord.
Come, pray, Madam, let me intreat you thither;
The time allows much liberty; Come, you muſt
Not deny the Count Lorenzo, 'twill break
His heart.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: 'Twill be ſcandalous I fear, Brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, no, piſh, ſcandalous; 'tis people of meaner
Quality ought to fear ſcandal; we are above
Thoſe things.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, the Muſick playing before, Except Beatrice and Felices.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Will you take the blame upon you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Lead on then, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Oh, my dear Fernando, how I long
To ſpeak with you alone!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Follow me, I'll lead you to a private place,
And there —

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Nay, what mean you, why ſo coy? Come, come,
I do not love it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Sure, I'me miſtaken, or the man is chang'd?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Nay, nay, dear miſtreſs, ne're hang back,
Come, kiſs me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Ha, ſure 'tis not his voice:
Pull of your Vizard, Sir, and then I will.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Look ye; now pull of your's, or elſe you break your Word.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: So I muſt; for I ſhould burſt with laughing elſe:
Ha, ha, ha, ha, was this your trim device?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What device, I had none?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: My ſiſter told me you would take
Fernando's name upon you, and would utter
Such monſtrous ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Of whom? of what?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why, 'tis a by-name 'twixt you and Quintagona;
They ſay you make love to her, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh, this Chit!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why, ſiſter, ſiſter, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Oh, you're a fine Gentle-woman!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Madam, I believe this was your own deſign,
Though you would put it on my pretty Miſtreſs;
I have ſeen you twitter at me before now,
But I underſtand a Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: A Jeſt, from who d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: From you, Madam; I were ill bred elſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, ſiſter, 'twere pity of his life elſe.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: So, ſo, this is fine!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Why, look Madam, here's one
Can end the doubt; Come hither Duck,
Did ever I make love to yee?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Make Love to me! hang thee.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Pa, Nurſe, pa, bug words!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nay, fie, Nurſe, t'uſe a Civil Gentleman ſo!

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Hang him, I ſay again, and you too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What, both on's, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Yes, him and you: Come, Charge,
What do you do amongſt them?
I won't ſtill be us'd ſo by a Graſhopper
And a Weather-Cock: why ſhould you be jeering me
Still? I bred you:
Beſides, God made me as well as you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, nor half ſo well neither;
I think I may ſpeak that without vanity.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Indeed, Nurſe, that was over-weening:
As handſom as your young Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Well, well, come Charge:
Nay, you're e'en fit for one another.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: I wiſh we were, Nurſe.

div.head: ACTUS III. SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Lorenzo leading Elvira; Alvaredo, Antonio, Ferdinando, Beatrice, Miranda, Quintagona; Servant and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.l: YOu're welcome, Gallants, infinitely
Welcome: there is no pleaſure
Like to this, Meet our Friends, and eat
Together! well fare England ſay I; for
I have been inform'd by credible Merchants,
That there they often meet together, eat
Together, and drink together. Come,
Come, take your Seats. Madam, what
Think you of an Ayre, as they are ſerving
In? nay, it ſhall be one of my own Compoſing;
For, ſome years paſt, when I was not ſo
Much taken up with buſineſs, I did employ
My time in Poeſie.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What you pleaſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Bartolo, bid them ſing the Song was
Sung when I acted the Sea-god with the
Cornucopia. Ah, Bartolo, thoſe were merry
Days! thou didſt Act Tantalus, I remember: troth
It was a very dainty Maſque; for all
The Company were kept in ſuſpence till the laſt, and
Did never comprehend what we meant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: That could not chuſe but be rare.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why, I have writ Verſes
That the beſt Wit in Sevil will never be able to
Underſtand.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Very likely, my Lord:
But I hope theſe we are to hear
sp.stage: They ſerve whilſt this is ſinging.
sp.l: Are not of that ſtrain.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: That you ſhall be Judge of.

lg.l: THoſe that do talk of Syſiphus ſtone,
Which makes him continually rolling to ſweat;
And call that a Hell, when in faith it is none;
For no Torment is like to the wanting of meat.
Then alack poor Tantalus, Tantalus cryes,
I only can feed by the ſight of my Eyes!
The Vulture that feeds on Prometheus heart,
Oh how happy does him poor Tantalus think!
For when he has quite conſumed that part
The Curſe of the Wretch affords new meat and drink.
Then alack poor Tantalus, Tantalus cryes,
I only can feed by the ſight of my Eyes!
When firſt againſt heaven the Giants did rebell,
It was not Ambition that made them ſuch Hectors;
But hearing of dainty Ambroſia tell,
They had a mind to taſte of it, and tipple the Nectar.
Then, &c.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Moſt excellent, faith!
But pray what Feet do you allow
Your Verſes, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Feet, ha, ha, ha!
Pox of Feet; let them regard them
That live by them.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, who are they?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why, Dancing-Maſters, Foot-men,
And Treaders of Mortar.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, my Lord, I can name you
Another ſort of men that live by their feet:
What think you of Cowards that run away
To ſave their lives? yet more
Miraculous, I have ſeen a man take breath
By his feet.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: May be, young Lady, you have heard ſo;
For I think I know the world as well as you;
And yet I do not remember the knowledge
Of any ſuch matter. Oh ſtay, may be it is
The little begging Boys that ſtand on their heads
In Normandy, as I have read.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, no, my Lord, it is the man
That teaches the Tereſian Nuns to play on
The Organs; for he blows the Bellows with his
Own natural feet.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By my faith, that is true;
'Twas well thought on I confeſs.
But come, Gallants, take your Seats;
Me thinks here is ſome body wanting:
Signior Ferdinando, where is your Brother?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I know not, my Lord;
But he will not fail to be here I know.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Fail! no marry I hope ſo,
H'll not ſerve his old friend ſo.
Come, Signior, I begin a Health.
Who waits there! Come, every man his glaſs:
Bartolo, ſee mine fill'd high.
sp.stage: They give every one a Glaſs: the Page fills his Lords from behind Bartolo.
sp.l: Signiors, a Health to all theſe
Ladies; ſend them rich, proper,
And able men to their husbands.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: S'death, Sancho, didſt thou ſee that conveyance.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: See it, yes, and do admire at it:
Pray, Sir, appear not yet, I'll make your Excuſe,
And take upon me to wait.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Who are you, friend?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: A ſervant to Signior Felices,
Who begs your Lordſhips pardon for his ſtay,
And deſires you will proceed in your mirth,
He hopes to wait on you before the end on't:

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: He ſhall be wellcome, friend.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My Lord, theſe Ladies will take it ill if you make
No diſtinction, they will think the time long
If they ſtay till I deſerve a husband.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I humbly crave their pardons,
Ladies, I thought no harm.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Fie, my Lord, you muſt not ſeriouſly conſider
What is ſpoke in mirth.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I find, my Lord, you are not acquainted with
The mad humour of my young ſiſter, ſhe ſays
Any thing to any body.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Say ye ſo, faith, young Lady, and I'll drink
Your health in particular for that too.
Nay, all theſe Ladies;
Some wine to all there (Bartolo, I ſay;
Boy be careful:)
And yours, pretty Couſin, thus I begin.

div.stage:
Whil'ſt they are all filling the ſecond time, Sancho ſteals a
Tankard, and when the Page has done behind, Bartolo, Emptyes the reſt in, and conveys it to the Cup-board.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mine's off, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I thank yee, Sir, Signior Alvaredo,
Signior Fernando, Come lets be merry,
Nay, wee'll have a Maſque anon; ſhall we not,
Faith wee'll all be very merry.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: As you pleaſe, my Lord.
What ſhall the ſubject be, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How Vulcan and Venus were Catcht in a
Net together by the cunning of that
Cuckoldly Rogue Mars.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We had better have a devout ſtory,
How Jonas ſwallowed the Whale, and ſpew'd him up
Upon the Coaſt of Gibraltar.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Truly, young Couſin, 'twas the Whale ſwallowed Jonas, As I it take; I'm ſure my book is falſe printed elſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Well, well, that's all one, it was one of them:

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That I confeſs;
Come, gallants, now to the fair Elvira, in particular,
Boy, ſome wine; wine there to thoſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Piſh, Bartolo, the Devil, here's none in;

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Away, ye fumbling Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah, where's this wine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord, the Cock is ſtop'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, your glaſs, your glaſs.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Ye Rogue, ye Dog, to the Cupboard.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, Enter, Sir, Enter, now is your Cue.
Enter, Fel. Ha, ha, ha, ha; ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: Comes in, ſtumbles upon the ſcreen, through which Lorenza's head falls, they all riſe.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Boutua, Criſpo, help me,
Here, my head is in the ſtocks.

div.stage: Sancho goes to help him, and cuts off half his Beard,

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: So, my Lord, ſo. Have I not trim'd him well?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Away, Rogue, be not ſeen.
How is it, my Lord? I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why, very well, very well, no harm,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: You'r very merry, Gallants, troth I'm glad to ſee you ſo, Come, wee'll in, and ſee the maſque, this ſcreen has diſcompos'd Our table, Bartolo, Cover again within.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What ails the fellow:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ails me, quoth'u?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pray walk in, Gallants, pray walk in;
I'm glad to ſee you thus merry,
Come, I'll lead the way.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Antonio, how the Devil came his Beard off?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I know not, I,

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis but half his Beard,
Come Ladies, let's in, I hope he wont perceive
It all this night.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is your doings, I'll lay my life,
But I ſwear 'twas quick, none could perceive how.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A man ſo much unfit to mix with mirth
Converts to poiſon what is others joy;
I have done wrong to my fair Beatrice,
Nor will her Brother, though he be my friend,
Forget an injury of ſuch a Nature,
Should ſhe diſcloſe it to him:
As ſure ſhe muſt.
Elvira too; his Miſtriſs; O my fate!
Nay, rather, O my falſhood!
Why, didſt thou ſwerve to my undoing ſo!
They both are fair. Nor was it that I thought
Elvira fairer then the other was,
But mans inconſtant nature ſtill muſt crave,
A Beauty that hee's not acquainted with,
Why ſhould it, though?
Oh, Ask the god of love, and ſurely he
Will ſay, that ranging proves his Deity.
Pedro, Come hither,
Here take this note, and leave it in my Brothers Chamber,
I am reſolv'd to leave the Town to night,
Make my things ready, you muſt follow me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I'll do all your Commands
With the moſt expedition I can,
Pray, maſter, let me wait upon you,
Whither is't you go?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To Salamanca; ſome troubles I expect,
And will not wait their ſad arrival.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What, here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I, here, what's that to thee?
I will away to night.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Where ſhall I meet you, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I ſhall not fail, Sir,
What ſhall I tell your other ſervants?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Bid them look well unto my houſe,
And there expect my farther Orders,
Let them pay my Brother
The ſame reſpect they would do me,
Make haſte, for I'll expect you where I ſaid.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha, what whim is this?
Preſto, be gone, and none knows why;
His Brother knows not on't neither,
There's ſomething more then yet I underſtand;
Oh, now I ſuſpect ſhrewdly.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Pedro, where is thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Where is your Maſter, friend?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why, Madam, I ſuppoſe you know.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Prithee, tell him I muſt needs ſpeak with him,
And have taken this opportunity to ſlip out.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Madam, hee's already on his journey;

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Journey, what journey?
O my I'll boding mind.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, you may truſt me,
I am to follow him preſently.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Truſt thee; I that I will with any thing,
Come, I'll go with thee,
But think'ſt thou hee's already out of Town?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I, I, Madam, he wait's our coming at. —

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Diſloyal man, but yet I'll be
Reveng'd or die in's ſight, —
Canſt thou not help me to diſguiſe my ſelf,
One of thy Maſters ſutes will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, I'm going home,
A ſute of his will be too big, borrow you another,
There's none can ſee you Enter,
I have the key of the back gate,
And there —

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I underſtand you, friend; ſome lead the way,
'Tis anger now, not love ſhall be my guide
Since he is falſe; Anger I'll be thy bride.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.l: I know? how ſhould I know where ſhe is?
You are her Counſeller, can't you tell?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Come, Come, leave your flirts and your tricks,
And do not fright me ſo;
I'm ſure the care I have ſtill had of you
Do's not deſerve this uſage.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.l: Away, away, do's your Reverend wit
Think to put a trick upon me?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I, I, Why, when did I play tricks,
Troth either tell me quickly, or I'll acquaint
Your Brother with your dealings,
I play tricks?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I, do, do Nurſe, hee'l thank ye for the care
You take of us;

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: O Heavens, I ſhall be Murthered?
If ever you'll have mercy on my rage,
Deliver me now from my Apprehenſions.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What apprehenſions, Nurſe, prithee ſpeak,
Art thou ſerious;

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I, I, too too ſerious;
Why I ſaw Don Fernando ſteal away;
And preſently after followed your ſiſter;
I thought it was but to talk a word
In private; but now alack aday, where are they!
O Fooliſh creature! could ſhe not tell me her mind,
I would have contriv'd all better,
Now if my Maſter ſhould miſs her,
Oh, here he is! what ſhall we ſay?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: What made him go away ſo ſuddenly,
I ſaw him dreſt in deepeſt Melancholly,
From the firſt moment that he entred here.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Faith, Sir, I know not;
'Tis a diſeaſe you never ſaw me troubled with.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Quintagona, where is my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Oh, Sir! ſhe has been very ill, and has
Tane Don Elvira's Coachhome.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Why did you let her go alone?
Go, follow, ye old fool.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I ſhall, Sir.
Come, young Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Don Felices, pray follow immediately to our houſe,
I muſt needs ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What, more devices?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, I am ſerious.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Well, I'll be with you ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Come, let's go ſee if that he be gone home,

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Content I'll wait upon you, Sir.

stage.hi: The Scene changes to the Country.

div.stage: Enter Ferdinando fighting with 3 or 4 Rogues.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, ſtay Villains, run from one man!

div.stage: Enter 2 more, and ſieze him behind.

sp.p: Are you ſo ſtout, Sir? Come, we can tame yee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Unhand me, Rogues;
Is it my Purſe ye want? take it,
And be gone.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.l: We thank yee for nothing;
You give us what yee cannot keep.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What then? is it my Life?
Who ſet ye on to do this miſchief?

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.l: No, that wee'l ſpare, if you'l be quiet:
Come, bind him, Fellows.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I muſt ſubmit to what I cannot help.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.l: To tell you true, we're men condemn'd
Unto the Gallies, Sir;
But lately we have ſlipt our Chain,
And are in danger of the Hermandad,
Whoſe Officers are all in queſt of us:
Having not wherewithal to carry us any whither,
We have pitch'd upon this Courſe
Till we can better provide for our ſafeties.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.l: Come, Sir, you muſt with us to our private
Retreat; and if Fortune favour us, we hope
This night to bring yee Company.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.l: Yes truly, Signior; for we are reſolv'd
To ſtop all Comers and Goers till morning.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You'l uſe me civilly, I hope;
It ſhall be worth ye more
Then what you otherways can get:
And if in the morning you will let me go,
I'le pay a better Ranſome then what I bear
About me.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: Yes, who ſhall be ſo bold to fetch it?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why, you or any man; I will engage my
Honour for your ſafety.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Come, Sir, wee'l talk of that within.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This I deſerve for my diſloyalty:
There's none of theſe yet half ſo bad as I.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: What ſay you now, Lady?
Ah, wo is me, I am undone, undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: So have I ſeen Rain trickle through an old
Crackt ceiling; Alas, poor Nurſe!

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: I, I, is this all your Care for your Siſter?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, I warrant you ſhe's in a better place,
And better Company.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Marry, God forbid; what, dead!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, no, I mean in a place and company
Of her own chuſing.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Ay me, here's my Maſter!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: See, Nurſe, ſee, I'le not ſtay the firſt Brunt.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: No, no, ſtay, Madam, it is
Signior Felices.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Oh you are welcome, Sir;
We're all undone here, my Siſter's loſt.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Loſt! how ſo? you jeſt ſure.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Nay, nay, 'tis too true;
I'le be hang'd if ſome Fellow has not
A finger in the Pye.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: What Pye? what finger, goody Quintelin?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Why, your ſweet Brother:
S'fleſh, a look'd like an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Why, do you know him to be otherwiſe,
Old mouldy-Chops.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: What if I do, or do not, I may ſay
My pleaſure, I hope, for all you?
Nay, faith, I dare ſwear you ſtand much
Upon your honeſt reputation too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, fye, Nurſe, fye, is this the way
To oblige a Gentleman in your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: My buſineſs! I'de rather
Never have my buſineſs done whil'ſt I breathe
Then be beholding to ſuch ſpindle-ſhanks.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I, I, you had need laugh,
But I hope my Maſter will not be fob'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Your Maſter?
Pray, young Miſtriſs, what do's this woman mean?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why truly, Sir, my ſiſter is gone,
And (ſhe ſuſpects) with your Brother.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: My Brother! Ha;
Why ſhould they do that by ſtealth
Which I know your Brother would not
Have diſallowed of; for none can doubt
The brightneſs of her honour, nor (I hope)
His honeſty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nay, truly, Sir, I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I have ſomething in my head —
As ſoon as I hear any thing,
I'le come and bring you tidings.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You oblige me, Sir, extreamly.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Miſtriſs, I kiſs your hands,
Adieu Lots wife — I like not this.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come, ſtop the ſource of thoſe moſt Orient Pearls.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Well, well, you ſhall ſee when your Brother comes home, What Orient words hee'll give us all.

div.head: ACTUS IV. SCENA I.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: IT cannot be:
He cannot be ſo much unjuſt; I was his friend.
Had he but ſpoke, he might have had
My full conſent; to ſteal my ſiſter from me;
It is not well; nor will I ſuffer it.
Tell your Maſter I muſt needs
Speak with him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Hee's not at home.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Is Signior Felices within?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Call him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: If I do finde he was conſenting to it
I'le firſt begin with him.
You'r wellcome, Sir,
Cannot you gueſs the reaſon;
Why I viſit you thus early?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: No, truly, Sir,
But I was coming to your houſe,
That I might farther underſtand a thing
I do not comprehend as yet.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: What was it, pray you?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: My Brother's gone,
And none as yet knows whither,
If he has truſted you with his intentions,
Pray eaſe me of a care I'me burthened with.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: 'Twas much about ſuch buſineſs
That I came hither to learn the truth of you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Concerning what, pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Know you any thing of my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not I, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: It may be ſo:
For though I am a Spaniard, yet I would not
Place the fault of one ill man
Upon the whole family.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I hope you do not mean my brother,
I muſt not hear you give him ſuch a title.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: If I do find he has done done me wrong,
You, and all the world ſhall hear much more:
Nay, in his blood I'le ſign my deep revenge.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Were you not friends?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: 'Tis that which makes his fault the greater.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: If he has ſin'd againſt the Sacred Rule
Of honourable friendſhip,
I'm his Enemy;
But if an Equal difference hath hapned,
I am his Brother, and dare own his cauſe.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: To ſhew you I'll be juſt,
Even to that Sacred Rule you lately mention'd,
I will not tax him, till I find all certain;
Do you but joyn with me to find the truth,
Which if it do confirm my juſt ſuſpitions,
And you continue in your late profeſſions,
My anger then will look upon your blood
To be the ſame as his;
Though there it ſhall not Reſt; But —

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, let's underſtand one another,
You ſeem to have a cauſe of juſt reſentment,
But why, as hitherto I'm ignorant of.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Sir, I am wrong'd in the Honour of our Houſe,
My ſiſter's gone, loſt, convey'd away.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: By my Brother, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I have reaſon to think ſo,
Is he not wanting at the ſame time?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: That is no Argument; for I believe
You would not have deny'd them your Conſent,
Their qualities are equal, and their fortunes
Hold no great diſproportion.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: That makes me know, if he be gone with her,
He means no fair play to her Honour.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Judge not ſo ill before you know all truths,
Whence went ſhe?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: From the Count Lorenzo's
In Donna Elvira's Coach.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Know of the Coach-man where he ſet her down.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: You Counſel well, come wee'll about it ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Twas well I could eſcape;
For I can do my Maſter ſervice here,
Beſides, it was not baſe to run away,
When like a Ram I can return with
Greater force; Rogues I ſhall have ye
In a Pound by and by; I remember
Your lurking hole, for they brought
In Priſoners ſo faſt they quite forgot me to binde,
And in the dark I ſlip'd away; But ſhe is
Faſt, and I perceiv'd my Poor Maſter bound
To his good-behaviour; I will not
Acquaint the Juſtice, that may diſpleaſe him,
If ſhe be taken with him; I'll firſt to his
Brother, whom I hope I may truſt; and according
To his orders — I long to be at theſe Rogues again.

div.stage: Enter Alvaredo, Felices, to Elvira's door.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.p: Stay, this is the houſe, we'll ring.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Who are ye? who would ye ſpeak with, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: With your Lady, friend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I ſhall acquaint her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Sir, I make bold with your Name?
Mine might have caus'd a denial.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I'm ſorry, Madam, I muſt give you this trouble,
But ſtill relying on your goodneſs,
I'm come to beg a Boon;

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Of me, Sir? what can it be?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: That you will have your Coach-man ſent for Hither.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Moſt willingly, Sir,
What do's he mean?
Bianca ſend for him,
But, Sir, you ſent in by another Name.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: My obligation, Madam, was the greater,
You would vouchſafe this Honour
Upon ſo ill a ſummons.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The Brother, Sir, to Don Fernando?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am ſo, Madam, and your humbleſt ſervant.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam, with your leave,
I muſt make bold to queſtion him in private.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Moſt freely, Sir,
Are you acquainted, Sir, with his intentions?
What buſineſs can he have,
With this my Servant?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Madam, I am, but dare not tell the ſecret,
Without his leave.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Where is your Brother, Sir?
How chance he is not with him?
I thought they were inſeparable.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This buſineſs do's concern my Brother.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Your Brother? how pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nay, I am in the dark my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: May I not know the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Any thing that concern'd my ſelf
You might Command; but this —

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: I am fool'd, O that old Hag.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Have ye learn'd any thing?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: No, nothing, pray, Sir, come with me,
Madam, I kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Pray let me ſpeak with you?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Your pardon, Madam, for ſome moments,
I'll wait on you again.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Diego, what was it he queſtion'd you about?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: If I had not carried a Lady home laſt night;
I anſwered him truth, I ſaw none but your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: A Lady, what Lady?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: He ask'd me too about one Signior Ferdinando.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Ha, a Lady! Don Fernando?
His ſiſter on my life.
O thou diſloyal man ——
Run, Diego run, tell him
I muſt needs ſpeak with him;
Now preſently ——
Come hither, Bianca,
In troth I am not well.

div.stage: Enter Sancho, in a ridiculous French Dreſs; The People and Boys after him.
Sings and Dance's a ridiculous Corant.

sp.speaker: Boys.
sp.p: O Brave Monſieur Kick-hoſe.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Away, ye Rogues, ta ran ta, ran ta, ta la ran.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What would ye have?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Prythee, ſlip in here, I muſt needs ſpeak with thee.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I come, I come.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: Pox, we have loſt the Frenchman.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Let's ſtay a little, hee'll come again ſtrait.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: We muſt hide our ſelves then.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.l: Nay, Prithee Sancho ſtay;
She has buſineſs,
She'll be ready ſtrait.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I have enough to do to free my ſelf
From the Cannalia; how I ſhall be troubled
With her!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, prithee, the more ſport the better?
Why art thou thus elſe?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Come, come, let her make haſte then.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Look yee, here ſhe is.

div.stage: Enter Quintagona like a Hollandts woman, upon a Broom.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nay, you may e'en pull off your Vizard,
Your face will ſerve for one.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Away, you Rogue, I go Incognito.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Adieu Nurſe, ſpeed yee well; I dare not ſtay,
The cry grows hot.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Gingle a wimbleton rid on a Mare.

div.stage: Enter the Thieves with Ferdinando and Beatrice bound; She in Mans Clothes.

sp.speaker: 1 Thief.
sp.p: Are the reſt all gone?

sp.speaker: 2 Thief.
sp.p: All vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Thief.
sp.p: Are the two Horſes ready?

sp.speaker: 2 Thief.
sp.p: I, I, ready, ready.

sp.speaker: 1 Thief.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, I hope you can't complain,
But we have us'd ye civilly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We cannot; nor would I, if I could, have ye
Puniſh'd, ſince ye but took to furniſh your
Neceſſities.

sp.speaker: 1 Thief.
sp.l: True, Sir; for we are young men,
Not condemn'd Slaves, as we firſt told yee;
Something we wanted to make us merry,
And having that, farewel.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, one word, Gentlemen; unbind us firſt,
And on our Honours wee'l not ſtir till you
Be out of ſight.

sp.speaker: 2 Thief.
sp.p: Come, Sirs, wee'l truſt ye.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Would yee but leave our Swords
'Twere noble in you; for I would not
Willingly go back to Sevil.

sp.speaker: 1 Thief.
sp.l: That you may ſay ye met with Gentlemen,
Wee'l get on Horſe-back, and e're we're out
Of ſight wee'l drop them; there you may
Take them up at leaſure.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I thank ye, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Thief.
sp.l: So much caution you'l give us leave to uſe:
Farewel, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Which way, fair Youth, do you intend?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I'le bear you company to fetch my Sword.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Come then, I'le wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: What do you mean to do?
Pray, Sir, content your ſelf:
I yet dare ſwear my Brother is not guilty of this
Thing; in fine, I am reſolv'd to find all out,
And then deal like a Gentleman with you.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir:
My old Hag told me ſhe was gone home
In Donna Elvira's Coach;
The Fellow ſwears he never ſaw her,
Nor any other woman but his own Lady.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: I cannot anſwer any thing to that.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Who's there within, Quintagona?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe is gone forth.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Gone out! whither? O damn'd Bitch!
She's of the Conſpiracy.
What, are you at home alone?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: We ſhall have you gadding too.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: What, my young Miſtreſs?
No, I dare anſwer, Sir, for her:
But pray ſtay you at home;
I'le be with you again ſuddenly,
And, upon my Honour, learn what truth I can:
Will this ſatisfie you?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: It muſt, for ought I ſee.
The Curſe of this Diſgrace, and this my ſtate,
Is, not to know where I ſhould place my hate.
Come Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, hiſt, come from that door.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Oh Pedro, where is my Brother?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: In Huckſters hands:
Pray, Sir, take what Servants with you you can;
I'le lead you where you ſhall find him.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.p: Saw'ſt thou my man?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No, Sir, nay pray make haſte,
I'le tell you all as I go.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: What ſhould this mean!
Come, Pedro, which way?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Why didſt thou not bring him with thee, Diego?

sp.speaker: Coa.
sp.p: He promis'd to be here as ſoon as I.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Go wait his coming at the Gate.
How cruel are the Extaſies of Love!
With what uneaſie Paſſions do they charm!
For womens Souls they to Convulſions move,
And for one good they cauſe a thouſand harms:
For thoſe that truly love have cruel Fears,
Black Doubts, and heart-afflicting Jealouſies.
Men falſhood only have; we only tears;
Their Perjury claims Tribute from our Eyes.
Why ſhould it though? Then tears ye come too late;
For never could ye falſhood yet reclaim;
Revenge more proper is to argue hate;
Revenge more fit for him that is to blame:
For he had all my Love and all my Wealth;
A Virgins Love her chiefeſt Jewel is:
Why ſhould he then abſent himſelf by ſtealth?
Why ſhould I mourn for what he did amiſs?
But I will ſeal my Love in fitter place,
Where more deſert does move to my relief;
But firſt he muſt revenge my ſad diſgrace,
And puniſh him that's Authour of my grief.
Oh, here he is!
Sir, you are welcome:
I hope you will excuſe the liberty I take
Of ſending for you.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam, you know your Power over me;
You may command all here.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, then tell me,
What Lady was that you examin'd my Servant about?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I only ask'd if he had carried home
Any other beſides your ſelf laſt night.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: But who, pray who waſt?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: No body, Madam,
That can poſſibly concern your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: You know not, Sir, what intereſt
I claim in your affairs.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I hope, Madam, though you cannot love me,
My troubles are not matter of mirth to you;
I never did deſerve that from you.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: I never had ſo baſe a thought.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Why, 'twas my Siſter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Who, Donna Beatrice! what of her?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: She's gone, and none knows whither.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Nor with whom? who do you ſuſpect?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: A man that was my friend:
I dare not name him;
I would not willingly miſtake.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: Who can that be?
Not that ſame Gentleman was here with you?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: The ſame; I cannot think on't with patience.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.l: It were too great a trial of your temper
But to perſwade you to it:
Such injuries ought not to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Nor ſhall they, whileſt I breathe.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Now I muſt tell you,
You were much to blame to be repulſt at one
Denial, Sir: May be I may be brought to love.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Ha! nay then farewell all grief,
I ne're can feel one having ſuch a joy.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: But Sir, though I have ever thought
Your honour fair,
Let not this extaſie blinde you ſo far
To make you loſe your yet fair reputation:
A man with ſuch a ſtain
Deſerves no Ladies love.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Nor will I beg it till I be as white
As your fair virgin thoughts.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: I now do claim ſo much an intereſt
That I would help you in your juſt revenge.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Heavens! how I glorie in your bleſſings now.
Madam, though on my knees I thank you;
None but my ſelf is wrong'd,
None but my ſelf ſhall right thoſe ill-plac'd wrongs:
And ſince my Miſtris preaches honour to me,
I'll give him what he not deſerves,
A fair and honourable trial
How ill ſuch injuries can be maintain'd.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: This nobleneſs makes me enamour'd of your virtues, Sir.
It's true, he not deſerves it;
But ſuch a cauſe is odds enough againſt him.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam, I am unfit as yet
To ſtay with you, and ſuch a ſtain about me,
Farewell, my fair, and noble Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: What have I done!
O! I have been too violent:
Ha! no: he that would break my heart
Deſerves my utmoſt crueltie.
Thou canſt not Love, with anger hold debate:
For thou art madneſs once being turn'd to hate.

div.stage: Enter Beatrice having ſnatch'd up both the Swords, Ferdinando going back before her.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou art a Villain and a Slave, I know:
Thou haſt committed murther on my Brother,
Why ſhouldſt thou ſteal away by night,
And he not with thee?
Didſt thou not ſay thy name was Ferdinando?
He lov'd thee much,
And would not leave his friend in a Diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What means the Youth? he's mad:
Your Brother! why, I know not who you mean.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: No, have you not ſeen ſome Features like to theſe?
I am Alonzo, Brother to Alvaredo,
A Student late at Salamanca;
And I will have account before you go
What is become of him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How ſtrong is Nature, when by hidden means
It works revenge for unknown injuries!

sp.speaker: Bea.
