sp.p: What anſwer can you make to this?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nothing: I do deſerve to dye,
Though your Brother's well, for ought I know.
Thoſe Eyes have murthered me already.
Oh my Beatrice, I do deſerve this puniſhment!
And from a Brother, a Brother too ſo like thee,
I would not grieve to take it ——
But why ſhould he conſtrain me to a ſuffering
I of my ſelf am willing to undergo?
He muſt not, ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſo much of guilt in thy falſe looks,
That I muſt ſure do well in puniſhing.

div.stage: Ferd. cloſes with her with his hat, and diſarms her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, now you are at my mercy.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Which I defie; here, Villain, do thy worſt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hadſt thou another face I would have kill'd thee
For that word:
Here take your ſword, young man,
And tempt not one given over to deſpair.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Not tempt thee? yes, I will with all the terms
That can provoke a courage in a Coward.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Prithee be gone, I will not fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Stay, perjur'd man;
See what thou haſt done:
sp.stage: She offers to kill her ſelf; he ſtrikes away her ſword.
sp.l: A woman that did love thee, will die for thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Heaven's, what do I hear!
Fall, fall, ſome mountain on this head,
To cover it from ſhame.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou art more cruel in preventing this,
Then all thy other perjuries;
What did thy poor Beatrice ever do,
To deſerve this uſage from thee?
Some cruel Tygre, or a Panther bred thee,
Thou never waſt nurs'd up with womens milk,
But ſuck'ſt the Air of falſhood for thy nouriſhment.
Ha, weep'ſt thou?
O thoſe diſſembling tears,
They're able once again to Cozen me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, Madam, ſtop your heart againſt all mercy,
I do confeſs they not deſerve your pity,
But do not hate my memory,
I am willing to expiate my crime,
Forgive, fair Beatrice, thy dying Martyr.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, for the ſame moment you ſhall hurt
That breaſt, I'll open mine, and overtake
Ye once more in your flight:
I'll do it.—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why, would ye have me live?
And ſo unfit to bear the name of man.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thoſe that had ſo much Love can never be
Without a mercy to forgive all faults.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh, my fair Beatrice,
Did you but know
How hard my honeſty has been Attach't,
You would ſome reaſon have to pity,
If not quite forgive my youthful fault;
For when I found that I had err'd,
I knew my ſelf unfit for you,
And was reſolv'd
Never to do another Right.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You could not, Sir, whil'ſt that you did me wrong:
But let this be your penance, tell me true,
It was not then averſion made you leave me,
But that your love had been divided.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It had ſo for a moment,
But if this heart do ever more rebel,
Let heaven afflict it with it's greateſt curſe.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Riſe, Sir, I will once more believe.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Ha, Swords drawn! my brother
On his knees! Hold Villain, hold.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha, brother, hold, for heavens ſake, hold,
Send away your Servant's, I have a ſtory for
Your Ear in private: be gone fellow's.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Oh, I underſtand ye,
Come, I'll conduct ye both unto the Town;
But, Madam, I'll not part ye, when you're down.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: PRay, my Lord, do not go abroad.
I dare not tell him, hee'll be out on's wits.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why not? why not, good Bartolo?
It is a day of mirth, I love to ſee them merry:
I was a merry man when I was young,
And lov'd theſe brave Devices;
Once on this time of Carnival I rid,
And with a Line and Hook I firk'd the peoples hats off,
'Tis true ſome unruly fellow's grew angry, and I was beaten,
But all the Ladies ſaid I fiſh'd for hearts,
They were ſo taken with my Garb.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Very likely, my Lord,
But why will you go now? you are not of an age
To Maſquerade it through the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What then, ye fool?
Think'ſt I have I cannot ſee others? ha?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord;
But here every body will ſee you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why, what then?
I have committed no treaſon.
I dare be ſeen; the fellow's drunk.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay, my Lord, what you pleaſe,
Would I durſt tell ye though.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Here wee'll ſtand; here we can ſee all;
Hark, I here ſome coming this way.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Oh, yonder's Game for me;
I have been game for others all this while.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A pleaſant couple;
Look, Bartolo, is not this very Pleaſant?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Oh, Yes, my Lord, very pleaſant.
You little think that you are the pleaſanter ſight of the two.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Moſt renowned, moſt worthy, and moſt munificent Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I thank thee, friend;
But prythee keep on thy way:
Do not addreſs thy ſelf in particular to me.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: To you, my Lord?
Why, to whom is reſpect, and addreſs more proper?
By this my beard, (which I think is a fair one.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Prythee keep it ſo ſtill with thy Bygotero's,
And about thy buſineſs.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, I am ſo, my Lord;
But, as I ſaid before, there is none in Sevil.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That will be ſooner, or more angry with you,
If you depart not preſently.
Doſt thou ſee how the Rabble gather?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What care I, or what need your Lordſhip care for the Rabble?
By this Beard I ſwear again,
And that's no ſmall Oath for a man of my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why, what profeſſion art thou of?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: A Barber, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A good trade; Nay, prithee away now.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Heaven forbid I ſhould diſpleaſe your Lordſhip,
By this Beard I would not do it for the Indies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now a plague on thy Beard, and a Pox on thee;
Nay, ſuch a Pox as may plague thy Beard too;
Here's ado with it.
Bartolo? prythee thruſt him away.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away, friend, be gone,
This Rogue has found him out.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Why, friend, the ſtreet is as free for me as you,
By my Beard, thy Beard, and thy Lords Beard,
I do infinitely Honour, Worſhip and admire.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ye Rogue, ſwear by my Beard?
Why, I can do that my ſelf; and will:
For if you be not preſently gone,
I'll have ye cudgell'd,
By theſe Honourable Muſtachio's I will;
Ha; why, Bartolo; what's this?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, come, duck, I will not ſtay to offend your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ten thouſand Devils, and their Dams,
My Beard? Hieco de Puta, my Beard.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Is quite gone on the one ſide, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why? thou Dog, thou Mungril,
Wouldſt thou let me come abroad,
And not tell me on't?
I have been ſport for all comers and goers.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, my Lord, you miſt it not when you
Came abroad; this fellow has bewitch'd you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Have mercy on me, Heaven!
A witch, a witch, Run Bartolo for an Officer,
I'll have him in the Inquiſition; a witch.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My Lord, he's gone;
Or by this time has transform'd himſelf
Into ſome other ſhape: Oh, he's a cunning Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: 'Tis too true;
But I, poor miſerable I,
What reſpect ſhall people pay me now?
No Beard no Brain they'l cry;
A Boy, a meer Tom-boy I ſhall appear:
My Servants too will make me ſtill their mirth,
Who have been ſtill their Terror.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: My Lord, I know a remedy for all.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What is't, good Bartolo? oh, ſome comfort, prithee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, my Lord, this time of Carnival
It may paſs for a youthful frollick,
And after Aſh-wedneſday,
You may ſay it was a Penance enjoyn'd you
By your Ghoſtly Father:
But for Decorum you muſt cut off
The other ſide; thus it is very ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thou counſell'ſt well; I would not have my
Servants ſee me ſo for a thouſand Piſtols:
Haſt thou no ſciſſers, good Bartolo?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but I have a knife.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come then, cut it off preſently.
sp.stage: Bartolo cuts, and Lor. makes faces.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: So, my Lord, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Come, Bartolo, I have ſeen enough for this day:
A Plague of all Witches! a beard-witch! O Diavolo!

div.head: ACTUS V. SCENA II.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: YOu may believe me, Sir,
He was as ignorant as you about her flight.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: But ſtill he us'd her ill;
And I ſhould bear her injuries as hard
As I ſhould bear my own.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, it was no injury,
It was unkind, I muſt confeſs.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Then I underſtand not well.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Why, Sir, he does owne he did make Love to her,
And that, as far as Modeſty could grant,
He had no reaſon but to think
She did love him;
But finding that his Youth and Love
Had brought him farther then he ought to have gone
Without acquainting you,
He was reſolv'd to ſlip away
About ſome feign'd buſineſs for a time;
And then, with your fair liking,
He would begin his Suit afreſh:
But ſhe, ignorant of his Deſign,
And learning from his man that he was fled,
Thought it a falſhood unto her,
And ſo reſolves for S. Tereſa's Monaſtery.
But he being found,
(Happily ſtopt laſt night by Thieves)
I hope to ſee her of another Order.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I do believe you, Sir, as you're a Gentleman;
And ſince your Brother is reſolv'd
To do her Reputation right,
I cannot erre, I think.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not poſſibly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: To ſhew you, Sir,
A perfect reconciliation to your Family,
I chuſe you for my friend,
And now will tell you all my ſecrets.
This buſineſs (I know not how)
Has brought me to a fair underſtanding
With my fair and dear Elvira;
And ſince my Honour now is cleer,
I'le to her ſtrait;
And you ſhall be a witneſs to me in't.

sp.speaker: Fel
sp.l: Why, Sir, had ſhe enjoyn'd
The cleering of your Honour?
Oh, I underſtand yee. I have a meſſage to her.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Not enjoyn'd me;
But, as one intereſſed in me,
Did counſel no neglect of what was fit.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Well, Sir, ſince you have honoured me
With the fair title of your Friend,
Let me adviſe you; I'le to her ſtrait;
It will appear much better,
For ſeveral reaſons: Here is the houſe,
Pray go you home, I'le wait upon you there,
And I doubt not but with ſuch happy News,
As the firſt Enterview you have
Shall bring a Period to your wiſhes.
The cleering of this buſineſs
Will appear better from him or me.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Well, Sir, I will be rul'd;
For though you are wild
I have ever found you
A gallant and an honeſt man. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I never, Sir, will give you cauſe to think the contrary;
If I do, tell my young Miſtreſs,
Whom really I do love.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Nay, I'le be your Spokeſman there.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Pray tell your Lady I needs muſt ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Now if I can but quite unhinge her love,
And fix it on Alvaredo,
All goes well——

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Madam, I'm come to wait upon you,
But with the Dread
That men approach offended Deities.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: How can that be?
You never did me wrong.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: It is a crime to be a kin to him
That ever could offend you,
Though by ignorance.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Thoſe that are wiſe
Pardon the Crimes of folly and miſchance;
But I find my ſelf griev'd by neither of theſe two.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Do but conſider your own Beauty, Madam,
The certain tyes it hath upon Affection,
The ever yet unconquered god of Love,
That dips his ſcorching Arrows in your eyes,
And hardens ſo their Points,
No Armour, though of ſtricteſt honeſty,
Is proof againſt their force:
All theſe are Arguments to move your mercy
To the forgiveneſs of a Crime
I now am come to beg a Pardon for.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Pray Sir, (without the Ornaments you now do uſe,
In rallying of a Lady never wrong'd you)
Tell me your Buſineſs; for as yet
I know not what you aim at.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Nor is it fit
I ſhould expreſs my ſelf in plainer terms:
But tell me;
If you had bargain'd for, nay, had bought a thing before me,
Would you not take it ill
I ſhould out-bid you in your price,
And by my Liberality corrupt the Merchant?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhould, Sir; neither were it juſt or honourable.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: This is my Brothers Caſe,
Who dares not live,
Nor think himſelf worthy the name of Man
Till you have pardon'd.
Remember, Madam, as I told you,
How much your Beauty can out-bid
All other Women.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Oh, I underſtand you,
And thank you, Sir, that you have ſpar'd my bluſhes:
But tell me, Sir, is not the Lady's name Beatrice,
That lay's her claim to your brother?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Madam, it is; And this Fernando bad me tell ye more,
He can requite your pardon with a Jewel
Of faireſt and of Richeſt price,
Her brother. ——

sp.speaker: Elvr
sp.l: Oh, Sir, I thank him,
My better reaſon has inſtructed me,
(I'll make an End't that which you were ſaying)
Her brother is a man, too good, of too much honor,
Nay, too much love to be refuſed by me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: And you too much of goodneſs and of merit
Not to be honour'd as a Saint,
By all that know you, and do hear you ſpeak,
I'll be gone, I ſhall talk my ſelf in time.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I can bear your Rallery.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I'm ſerious,
Why, Madam?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, if you are ſo,
Pray bring Signior Alvaredo hither,
Your brother too may come, and his fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Sir,
I ſhall expect your Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: It's we'll your gone,
I had ſpoyl'd all elſe; my Pate
Was hammering devices for my own advantage,
Carnival do ye call it,
I could Maſquerade it bravely with her.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Nay, Prythee Sancho conſider,
I never dare go home again;
Is not this more wealth then ever thou couldſt
Hope for; 'tis the porloyning of thirty years
Service, two thouſand crowns will not buy
Them, why ſure I'm not ſo old; nor
Yet ſo unhandſome, but that an
Honeſter man would bleſs his fortune for ſuch a match.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nay, now ye have ſpoil'd all,
If you had not ſpoke that word
I would have taken pity on you,

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Pity on me? thou Raſcal,
Thou Son of many Fathers I'll, have thee to know
(But that I took thee for a pleaſant
And an honeſt dealing fellow)
I ſhould ſcorn thee; S'fiſh in my old Miſtriſs time
I might had a Knight of Calatrava,
Nay, within this twenty years, as much has been offered me
Twice; two brave Knights,
Pity on me; foh, Garlick ——

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: May be ſo: ta ran, ta ran tan.

div.stage: Sings and Dances up and down careleſly.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Well, Sancho, well;
Have I for this truſted thee with my reputation,
Gone all about the town with thee;
Nay, Did not leave thee, nor hide my ſelf
When the Boys had ſnatch'd away my Vizard,
Oh, Sancho, Sancho, thou art falſe as other men,
And I a moſt unhappy Virgin.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Boutoua, Diavolo, ſhe has moiſture in her,
This is the firſt Lady ever wept for Sancho,
Have comfort my deareſt duckling,
I will be thine by day and night,
And get a whole litter of Sancho's on thee?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Oh, Sancho, Sancho, Abuſe not good Nature,
I am tender, be not thou Harſh.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes, as tender as whit-leather,
Well, come ſpit in thy hand and Clap here,
Is't a match, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: A match; and all theſe are thine.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Come, we'll Dance to our Wedding,
Strike up Rogues, tan ta, ta rin ta, ta ta ra.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Oh, Brave Rogue,
Where have you been all this while?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Nay, pray, Sir, forbear,
A curſe will light on him
That parts man and wife.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Quintagona thy wife?
Now ſend thee joy thou pretty maid.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: And thee a halter, thou ſneering fellow.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh, fie ſweet-heart, he is my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: What then; he's none of mine,
There's ne'r a man in Sevil ſhall be my Maſter.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I have a fine time on't then.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sancho, come hither, a word,
Nay, take her with you, make haſte
I ſhall be there before thee
Boy, Hony-Comb.

div.stage: Enter Antonio in Maſquerade, And Fidlers in Maſquerade like Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here, friends, this is the houſe,
The Accident hapned laſt night,
You know the tune I made the Song to

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: I, I, Come, ſhall we begin.

lg.opener: To the Tune of the Broom, the bonny Broom.

lg.l: THe Beard, the Beard, the bonny bonny Beard,
Oh, it was of a wondrous growth,
But eating too faſt
His ſpoon he miſplac'd,
And ſcalded it off with the broth.
Chorus ſtill of Muſick. But O what ſight, one part did ſtand upright,
As if it had guarded his face.
The other off by the ſtumps,
Which needs muſt put him in a dumps,
Had quite deſerted the place.
Which makes it plain, that that which doth remain
Doth Centry ſtand for two,
The other ſide was loſt,
And beaten off his Poſt,
For ſome think that it lay, Perdue.
Oh, the Beard, the Beard, the bonny, &c.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Gentlemen, remove your mirth,
My Lord is very ill, nay, pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ill, how come he ill prithee?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, a grief he has lately conceiv'd,
For his ſins, I think.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why think'ſt thou ſo, man?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, he has ſhav'd himſelf!
And vows to wear Sackcloth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What a dam'd hypocrite!
Muſt Religion be the Cloak of the Jeſt
Was put upon him?
Play, Gentlemen, play,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.stage: at the window with a Gun.
sp.l: You Flemings, Boarachio's
You Pantalons de mi culo,
Dogs, Rogues, either from my
Houſe, or I'll ſend ſome of ye to the
Devil before your time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, my Lord, is this your Conſcience?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hang ye, Rogues,
Bartolo, Come up, here, and ſhoot this off,
I dare not for, fear it ſhould recoil,
Slaves, he'll pepper ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sirrah, I'll tickle ye with this, are ye
Budging, ye Cackafuego.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, by this Beard.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh, Hieco de puta, Et tu Brute,
Nay, then, I will be ſick indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I, do, and Die,
The Devil a tear will be ſhed for thee,
Bartolo, go and get Legacies for all thy friends,
Of Lamprey Pies, and Sturgeon.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Ha, theſe know him, Adieu, Signiors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, Nay, here we'll give
A leſſon or two, 'tis the houſe of Signior Alvaredo;
His two ſiſters are fair Ladies.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Ha, Muſick here! 'tis either meant to my brothers
Wife, or to my young Miſtriſs,
Neither pleaſes me; who are ye? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's that to thee, thou man of Metal?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That ye ſhall ſee ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Felices, Why, hark ye, man?
What freak's this?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Is't you, a plague, I was going to fetch a
Servant, or two, to entertain your worſhip's;
Who are thoſe with ye?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Friends, friends, O my worthy friends!
Sirra, I have been with him,
And teas'd him out of his Wits,
Come, Come, we'll thither again; prithee
Walk this night with us.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Faith, I cannot, I have buſineſs,
Oh, you are wellcome, hark-ye!

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Oh, my beſt Angel! can this be?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Go trie, I'll be there with you ſtrait,
And bring all the Company with me,
Will you not give me leave to call my
Young Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Any thing, what you pleaſe.
Adieu, I cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I'm ſorry I cannot bear ye
Company, I can aſſure ye, my heart
Earns to leave ye, but buſineſs,
A thing you know I much delight in,
Calls me from you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Troth, me-thinks of late thou haſt a buſie
Countenance; Come, what Wench
Are you to lead into a fools paradiſe?
Some ſuch thing I'm ſure it muſt
Be, the Devil could never fix any
Other buſineſs upon thee.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Away, away, you are wilde fellow's, I am
Not fit for your Company; But if
You will preſently break all Lorenzo's
Window's, or ſo, I am for ye, but I
Cannot ſtay, faith I cannot, night blades
Hark ye, you'll do well to carry your
Muſick to your Siſters houſe, Antonio,
There may be uſe of ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How, ſoe, prithee, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Nay, no queſtions, Come if you will;
If you won't, chuſe, bonus Noehios.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, we will go.

div.head: ACTUS V. SCENA III.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: NAy, Sir, I find, in all appearance,
You have much reaſon to be ſatisfi'd,
But yet there remain ſome ſcruples
That I muſt cleer my ſelf in.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I hope I am not quite ſo Dull,
If they concern my Honour,
But I ſhould be as ſcrupulous
As do's befit a Gentleman to be; and Madam—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Nay, Signior, you miſtake me now,
I have been, and am your Siſters friend;
I only muſt ask ſome queſtions.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam, what you pleaſe;
They will all be here preſently.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Madam, here is Muſick and Maſquers
Come, one I believe is Signior Antonio.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Bid them enter.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam, will yee once more repeat,
This hand and heart is mine?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I do. Oh you are welcome, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, here is more Company.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Let them come in. Come Brother, you may
Unmask, you are known;
Beſides, you muſt be witneſs of a thing
That does concern me highly.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: What is't pray, Madam?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: By and by you ſhall ſee.

div.stage: Enter Ferdinando, Beatrice, Felices, Miranda, Sancho, Quintagona, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Madam, you are welcome hither;
I muſt beg the favour to ſpeak with this
Gentleman in private; you will not ſure
Be jealous, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Oh Madam, you wrong your Servant.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: Now, Sir, what good excuſe
Have you fram'd for your diſloyalty?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Such as muſt crave your mercy,
Not juſtifie my Crime.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: But I muſt claim your Promiſe,
That nothing can diſpenſe you from:
Speak, Sir, ought not I to have the fair diſpoſal of yee?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here, Madam, diſpoſe my life:
I do ſubmit unto your Cenſure.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.l: No, Sir, your Perſon I will diſpoſe of: Come, nay, come,
You have ſpar'd my bluſhes,
And I will now indulge your ſhame.
Here, Madam, let me cloſe your hands:
And pray, Sir, do as much for me here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: With all my Soul:
And may the Heavens continue ſtill
Your Love and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Thanks, friend, I hope you ſtill were ſo,
And I miſtaken in my Doubts.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am, and ever will be ſo,
Or let your Siſter hate me,
And that's the worſt of Curſes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Madam, I ſent you Muſick:
One Dance is both proper for the time,
And indeed looks ſomething like the latter
End of a Play, which ſhould go off merrily:
Only one thing is wanting, I ſhould be married
Too here; but plague on't, ſhe's too young.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And you too mad.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Well, by that time you are fit for me
I ſhall be fit for you; three or four years
Will ſtrike deep towards gravity:
In the mean time, here's my hand, If I like yee then
As well as I like you now, thou ſhalt have me
Round and all ſound.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis well if I have.
Nay, prithee ſweet Quintagona bluſh not,
We know that thou art married,
Meerly ſtole away by this young Gallant,
Signior Sancho.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Come, come, ſtrike up.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Ladies, how like you this?
Gentlemen, do you all ſpeak; are ye pleas'd?
'Tis new; for I dare boldly ſay,
'Tis the firſt Carnival y'ere ſaw in Play.
